body_text.text: As the power of HARIOM lies in oligo-embedded enzymatic activity, we 289 wondered if we could further enhance the sensitivity by amplifying two genes instead 290 of just one. To test this, we used primers against ORF-1ab as well as N-gene. We 291 tested two different PCR protocols for this using cDNA from nasopharyngeal swab 292 preparation of SARS-CoV-2 positive patient, SARS-CoV-2 negative patient and non-293 template control (NTC). In one strategy, we used H-inv containing primers for both 294 genes together in one-step PCR for 35 cycles, in another strategy, we used non-H-inv 295 primers for first 10 cycles, followed by another PCR with this product using H-inv 296 containing primers for next 30 cycles. We observed a clean single band corresponding 297 to ORF-1ab as well as N gene in first strategy (both genes yielding almost similar 298 product size 106 and 108 bps) with no amplification either in SARS-CoV-2 negative 299 subject or NTC. These results were reflected in clean colorimetric distinction across 300 samples and in absorption spectra at 450 nm ( Figure 5A) . However, in two-step PCR 301 we observed a lot of background in SARS-CoV-2 negative and NTC samples, which 302 was also reflected in colorimetric readouts and absorption spectra at 450nm. (Figure  303 5B). Thus, we decided to follow the one-step PCR strategy moving forward. 304 305 During initial phases of testing, NP/oral swab suspended in VTM was 306 standard matrix that was used for viral testing using RT-PCR. However, the sample 307 collection method was inconvenient for the sample provider and at the same time 308 posed exposure risk to health personnel. We spiked serially diluted copies of viral synthetic RNA from 317 10 6 to 10 0 copies in inactivated saliva, performed cDNA synthesis and PCR, followed 318 by detection using HARIOM. While using N-gene alone, we were able to detect 10 3 319 viral copies (Figure 5C, 5D) . We sought to test 356 a recently developed RNA extraction free protocol for detection of nucleic acids from 357 saliva, that has been recently approved by FDA. We first tested the detection of beta-358 actin from saliva of four healthy individuals for presence of beta-actin RNA using 359 previously used primer set. In conclusion, we demonstrate that the modified HRPZyme sequence we used in 377 conjunction with our optimized protocol presented here holds great promise for 378 detection of nucleic-acids. HARIOM offers a powerful and generalized method for 379 detection of nucleic-acids from a variety of sample matrices, ranging from 380 nasopharyngeal swab, oral swab and direct saliva without the need for RNA isolation. 381

body_text.text: We also demonstrated its capability in detection of SARS-CoV-2 infection from 382 clinical specimen. We do acknowledge the limitation that the method presented here 383 still is dependent on availability of PCR instrument, but we believe that in future 384 iterations this could be taken to instrument-independent platforms, such as RPA, 385 further enhancing the sensitivity of reaction while marinating the simplicity of 386 colorimetric readout. One major limitation of the study that we feel is not being able 387 to test on enough clinical samples so as to accurately gauge sensitivity and specificity 388 as per clinical requirements, but as this is just a proof of principle demonstration of 389 the technique, we hope to address this in future studies. Early detection of infection via 58 mass-screenings of societies is paramount in curtailing viral spread as mounting 59 evidences suggest spread of infections by asymptomatic individuals. (F et al. 2020; 60 Hogan et al. 2021) Such information is also pivotal for defining effective public 61 health policies. (Hinchman et al. 2020) Several methods are being developed for 62 detection of SARS-CoV-2 infection. These methods rely on either detection of viral 63 nucleic acids using RT-PCR, LAMP, SHERLOCK, (Broughton et al. 2020; Esbin et 64 al. 2020; Park et al. 2020; Shen et al. 2020) viral antigen (Mak et al. 2020; Porte et al. 65 2020) or host's immune response to infection (ELISA, antibody based rapid 66 diagnostic tests). (Kontou et al. 2020; Petherick 2020) Each of these tests has its own 67 utility and utilization window. For example, nucleic acid and antigen-based tests are 68 useful for detection of active infection while antibody-based tests can identify 69 exposure to viruses and may indicate presence of protective antibodies. peroxidase-mimicking DNAzyme (HRPzyme) is a short DNA 73 sequence comprising of guanine (G)-rich sequence, which folds into a G-quadruplex 74 structure which is stabilized upon forming a complex with hemin. (Travascio et al. 75 1998) HRPzyme is able to catalyze the peroxidation of various HRP substrates ) (ABTS) in the presence of H 2 O 2 giving a colorimetric readout. The 78 short sequence of HRPZyme permits the possibility of primer integration in a manner 79 amplification of the target genomic region. Various HRPZyme and G-quadruplex 81 based assays (Xi et al. 2020) have previously been developed for detection of 82 pathogens such as Staphylococcus aureus, (Mondal et al. 2018) Salmonella enterica 83 Typhimurium, (Kim et al. 2018) norovirus (Batule et al. 2018) and even coronavirus 84 (Anantharaj et al. 2020) However their low sensitivity inhibited human applications. 85 Here we report the use of a modified HRPZyme sequence (Li et al. 2016) with 86 enhanced sensitivity for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 infection in human samples. 87 HRPZyme Assisted Recognition of Infection by Optical Measurement (HARIOM) 88 offers the dual advantages -specificity of PCR and enhanced sensitivity of an enzyme 89 catalyzed reaction. Other notable features of the system include its robustness, 90 requirement of minimal technical knowledge and usage of inexpensive reagents, 91 making it ideal for use in low-resource settings and for mass screenings. 92 93 As HARIOM utilizes the power of oligo-embedded enzymatic activity, it 94 offers the possibility of additive effect from simultaneous amplification of multiple 95

The workflow consisted of collecting clinical specimen from suspected 156 subjects in the form of nasopharyngeal swabs/ oral swabs resuspended in viral 157 transport medium (VTM) or saliva (Figure 1A). This is followed by extraction of viral 158 RNA using extraction kit, (Wyllie et al. 2020) and cDNA synthesis using random 159 hexamers. cDNA thus synthesized is then amplified using SARS-CoV-2 genome 160 specific primers, namely for ORF1ab and/ or N-gene. The reverse primer consists of 161 the HRPZyme complementary sequence (H-inv primer) in a manner that the 162 functional HRPZyme sequence would only be formed upon amplification of the 163 SARS-CoV-2 gene products (Figure 1B). We used TMB volume ranging from 10 l to 100 l per well, keeping hemin 258 concentration at 50 M, as optimized previously, PCR product volume as 20l, H 2 O 2 259 concentration at 0.25 l per reaction of 3% H 2 O 2 . This resulted in varying final 260 volumes of reaction for same input ingredients, due to varying volume of TMB. We 261 found that both, 10 and 25 l TMB per reaction gave clearly distinguishable output 262 after 60 minutes of incubation, with 25 l providing better clarity between amplicons 263 with or without HRPZyme (Figure 4A). 264 265 Finally, we sought to optimize the H 2 O 2 volume per reaction. H 2 O 2 acts as 266 oxidizing substrate for HRP, that reduces colorless TMB to its blue-green (one 267 electron loss oxidation state) or yellow (two electron loss oxidation state) form. We 268 tested different volumes of 3% H 2 O 2 , ranging from 0.1 l to 1 l per well, keeping 269 of 75 l.
